intro: Petiveria corrientina, commonly known as the Mexican mint or corrientina, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows as a herbaceous perennial, reaching heights of up to 1 meter, with slender stems and compound leaves. Its small, white to greenish flowers are clustered in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. It is often cultivated for its fragrant leaves used in traditional medicine and as a culinary herb.
